prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for refusing to let my neighbors park in my free spot
To cut a long story short my neighbor has about 4 cars, husband, wife + kids. I have lived inside this house for the past 18 years, they moved in about 3/4 years ago. At first I had no issues letting them park in my parking spot because I had no car. I’m not an asshole so I let them park their car there for years free of charge. 

A few months ago I had the wife approach me and ask me if she could take half of my front garden to build herself a porch, I said no. I live in the UK so we don’t have porch where you can just park your car, it’s all street parking. 

After I turned down her request she has stopped greeting me whenever she says me, fine I don’t care. I’d like to note at this point her family members were still using my parking spot. 

Today she approaches me and informs me that she will start building her driveway taking up half of my property. I’d like to note that I don’t own the house, I just rent it. The council owns the house. She tells me that the council has given her permission to take up half of my front garden to build her driveway, lol ok. I again informed her that I don’t consent and that she cannot go ahead with her building plan. 

This kind of entitlement has enraged me so I called up my brother who had a car and told him to come and park in my parking spot, he did. As soon as my brother parked his car, my neighbor the husband came out yelling at my brother telling him to move his car that was when I told him that he and his family members could no longer park on my spot. 

The whole driveway issues confuses me and I will be calling the council later today to try and stop this crazy woman taking half of my garden!
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to work through this. The user is asking if the author of the story is in the wrong. Let me read through the situation carefully.

So, the author has been letting their neighbor park in their parking spot for years because they didn't have a car. Now they have a brother with a car, so they want to use the spot themselves. The neighbor, who has four cars, tried to take half the garden for a porch, which was denied. Then the neighbor claimed permission from the council to take the garden for a driveway. The author then told their brother to park there, leading to conflict when the neighbor tried to stop them.

First, I need to consider UK property laws. The author rents the house, so the council owns it. Front gardens can be part of the property, but if the neighbor is trying to take part of it, that would require proper consent. The author's refusal to let the neighbor park is about their own parking spot, which they've used as a free spot for years. But now they need it for their brother's car. The neighbor's attempt to build a driveway without the author's consent might be an issue, especially since the author doesn't own the property. However, the council's permission might be a factor here.

In the UK, if part of a property is being altered, the owner (in this case, the council) would need to grant permission. If the neighbor is trying to take part of the author's garden, the author's refusal is valid. The author's action of parking their brother's car to block the neighbor's access might be seen as asserting their own right to the parking spot, which they've been using for years. However, the neighbor might argue that the parking spot is shared or part of a communal area, but the author's description suggests it's a personal spot.

The key points are: the author renting the house, the neighbor's unauthorized construction, and the parking spot being a free space the author allowed others to use. The author's response to stop the parking and construction seems to be defending their property rights. However, since the house is rented, the author's rights might be limited compared to owning the property. But the neighbor's claimed permission from the council isn't clear—maybe the actual permission is for the driveway, but the author's garden is part of the property they have a right to protect.

I think the author isn't in the wrong because they're asserting their rights to their own property and parking spot, even though they rent. The neighbor's actions without proper consent are the issue here. So the answer would be B.
